titleStmt.title: A letter from a worthy gentleman in Yorke-shire, to his friend a member of the honorable House of Commons Declaring 1. That the Parliament hath, and continually ought to use their zealous indeavours and heartie desires for a thorow reformation in Church and common wealth. 2. That the same meanes the prelates used ... and confounded their carnall wisdome. 3. That the Papists in England and Ireland by their own barbarous, savage and inhumane practises, ... will be the actors and authors of their own tragedies. 4. Shewing through the honourable houses of parliament be by many evill affected people scorned and derided, ... 5. The enemies of the Parliament and kingdome, are papists to root out religion the clergie for bishopricks and pluralities, ... 6. And lastly advise to the Parliament to go on with alacrity but not one foot but to God, to heavenly ends, divine rules, apparant truths, in the churches walkes, and then they shall not want the protection of the Almighty.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in the Folger Shakespeare Library, Washington, D.C..
